item.title: What am i doing wrong
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“hadlich4, post:13, topic:546810”][quote author=tyb97 link=topic=665706.msg4450706#msg4450706 date=1411152971]

The title of the video is incorrect.

Why is that? Keep in mind im code stupid

This program was not written in “Javascript”…
[/quote]

Well then what was it written in? I used eclipse ide andit extends java applet. Is there a difference between java and JavaScript[/quote]
It was written in Java. You literally just said that.

Key differences between Java and JavaScript: Java is an OOP programming language while Java Script is an OOP scripting language. Java creates applications that run in a virtual machine or browser while JavaScript code is run on a browser only. Java code needs to be compiled while JavaScript code are all in text.
http://www.java.com/en/download/faq/java_javascript.xml

Read full topic

item.title: What am i doing wrong
item.dc:creator: @hadlich4 hadlich4
item.description:
@hadlich4 wrote:

Well not sure if y’all care ha but I finished the basic Login System I was working on
I know it’s very nooby but I’m a beginner, just learning so this is a good achievement for me my and first java achievement outside of rs related stuff. so it writes the username and password entered into a .txt file and into a folder called characters, and if the username/pass are correct it shuts the applet off if its incorrect then it tells you its wrong or the username is already taken.

[youtube]http://youtu.be/KCIJETlVc94[/youtube]

Read full topic

item.title: What am i doing wrong
item.dc:creator: @tyb97 tyb97
item.description:
@tyb97 wrote:

[quote=“hadlich4, post:5, topic:546810”][quote author=tyb97 link=topic=665706.msg4450332#msg4450332 date=1410912991]
I hate you Ryley, you took the easy route this time >.<

I went ahead and wrote a cleaner example.

[code=Java]
import java.util.Scanner;
import java.util.stream.Stream;

public class LoginChecker {

private static User[] users = { new User("Jim", "12345"),
		new User("Carl", "carls-password"), new User("Mopar", "or-no-car") };

public static void main(String... args) {
	Scanner scanner = new Scanner(System.in);

	System.out.println("Please enter a username.");
	String name = scanner.nextLine();
	System.out.println("Please enter the password for this account: " + name);
	String password = scanner.nextLine();
	System.out.println("Attempting to login: " + name + ", with password: " + password + ".");
	scanner.close();

	String answer = validateUser(new User(name, password)) ? "Sucessful login!" : "Login failed.";
	System.out.println(answer);
	System.exit(0);
}

private static boolean validateUser(User user) {
	return Stream.of(users).anyMatch(u -> u.equals(user));
}

private static class User {

	private String name;
	private String password;

	public User(String name, String password) {
		this.name = name;
		this.password = password;
	}

	public String getName() {
		return name;
	}

	public String getPassword() {
		return password;
	}

	@Override
	public boolean equals(Object object) {
		User user = (User) object;
		return user.getName().equalsIgnoreCase(name) && user.getPassword().equals(password);
	}
}

}[/code]

Which you can see it also did what AtomicInt_ said would fix it…

[hr]

EDIT: Turned this into a learning experience and Atomic helped me with learning some more Java 8 practices, applied in the new code, if you can be bothered to look at it OP.

[hr]

I’m so bored… Made more improvements

[code=Java]import java.util.Scanner;
import java.util.stream.Stream;

public class LoginChecker {

public static void main(String... args) {
	Scanner scanner = new Scanner(System.in);

	System.out.println("Please enter a username.");
	String name = scanner.nextLine();
	System.out.println("Please enter the password for this account: " + name);
	String password = scanner.nextLine();
	System.out.println("Attempting to login: " + name + ", with password: " + password + ".");
	scanner.close();

	String answer = validateUser(name, password) ? "Sucessful login!" : "Login failed.";
	System.out.println(answer);
	System.exit(0);
}

private static boolean validateUser(String... params) {
	return Stream.of(User.values()).anyMatch(u -> {
		if (u.getName().equalsIgnoreCase(params[0]))
			return u.getPassword().equals(params[1]);
		return false;
	});
}

private enum User {
	JIM("Jim", "12345"),
	CARL("Carl", "carls-password"),
	MOPAR("Mopar", "or-no-car");

	private String name;
	private String password;

	private User(String name, String password) {
		this.name = name;
		this.password = password;
	}

	public String getName() {
		return name;
	}

	public String getPassword() {
		return password;
	}
}

}[/code]
[/quote]

So where does this store username and password?[/quote]
It doesn’t, I was only writing an example for the portion you were having issues with.

Read full topic

item.title: What am i doing wrong
item.dc:creator: @hadlich4 hadlich4
item.description:
@hadlich4 wrote:

For some reason its like its not checking if the file exist correctly any solutions?

	  static void UsernameAvailability(String user) throws IOException{
		  user = ufloc;
		  File f = new File("+ufloc+");
		  
		  //if file does exist
	      if (!f.isDirectory()) { 
	    	  ReadLines(ufloc, 3, 3);
	    	  System.out.println("file does exist");
	    	  System.out.println(""+LinNum+"");

	  //if file does not exist
	      } else if (!f.exists()) {
	    	  System.out.println("file does not exist ");
//Since file does not exist write file
	  	          PrintWriter out = new PrintWriter(new BufferedWriter(new FileWriter("C:\\Users\\PeytonAree\\workspace\\Delta Remake\\src\\characters\\"+name+".txt")));        
		         

	    		
	    	out.println("USERNAME =");
	    	out.println(""+name+"");
	        out.println("PASSWORD =");
	    	out.println(""+pass+"");
	    	out.close();
	      }
	  }

ufloc is the characters file directory

Read full topic

item.title: What am i doing wrong
item.dc:creator: @Tree Tree
item.description:
@Tree wrote:

[quote=“hadlich4, post:3, topic:546810”][quote author=AtomicInt_ link=topic=665706.msg4450329#msg4450329 date=1410912309]

So I’m writing a little mini login code and this is what i got.
The problem is at void checkpassword(). The console is not noticing when the password is correct.
Sorry if my code is sloppy I’m still learning.

[code]package server;

import java.util.Scanner;
import java.io.*;

public class LauncherReworked {

//ints strings etc
static Scanner userInputScanner = new Scanner(System.in);
public static String ufloc = "";
public static String name = "";
public static String pass = "";
public static String LinNum;




  public static void main(String[] args) throws IOException {
        System.out.print("\nType Your username.");
        String Username = userInputScanner.nextLine();
        System.out.print("\nType Your password.");
        String Password = userInputScanner.nextLine();
        
        name = ""+Username+"";
        pass = ""+Password+"";
        ufloc = "C:\\Users\\PeytonAree\\workspace\\Delta Remake\\src\\characters\\"+Username+".txt";
        //find out if username is available
        
        UsernameAvailability(name);
        CheckPassword(name, pass);
        
        
        
        
  }
  
  
  
  
  
    static void ReadLines(String fileName, int startLine, int endLine)  {
		String line = null;
		int currentLineNo = 0;
		

		BufferedReader in = null;
		try {
			in = new BufferedReader (new FileReader(fileName));
	    	
			//read to startLine
			while(currentLineNo<startLine) {
				if (in.readLine()==null) {
					// oops, early end of file
					throw new IOException("File too small");
				}
				currentLineNo++;
			}
			
			//read until endLine
			while(currentLineNo<=endLine) {
				
				line = in.readLine();
				if (line==null) {
					// here, we'll forgive a short file
	// note finally still cleans up
					return;
				}
				LinNum = line;
				
				System.out.println(line);
				currentLineNo++;
			}
			
		} catch (IOException ex) {
			System.out.println("Problem reading file.\n" + ex.getMessage());
		} finally {
			try { if (in!=null) in.close(); } catch(IOException ignore) {}
		}
	}


     
     
  
  static void UsernameAvailability(String user){
	  user = ufloc;
	  File f = new File("+ufloc+");
	  
	  //if file does exist
      if (!f.isDirectory()) { 
    	  ReadLines(ufloc, 3, 3);
    	  System.out.println("not available");
    	  System.out.println(""+LinNum+"");
	  
  //if file does not exist
      } else if (!f.exists()) {
    	  System.out.println("available");
  
      }

  }
  
  
  
  static void CheckPassword(String user, String password){
		 user = ufloc;
		 password = LinNum;
		 if(pass == password){
			 System.out.println("Password Correct!");
		 } else {
			 System.out.println("Wrong Password");
		    	System.out.println("correct pass"+LinNum+"");
		 }
		 
		 
	 }

}[/code]

Strings cannot be compared with ==, use .equals instead.
[/quote]

sweet thankyou so much learning more everyday this is awesome[/quote]

Easy mistake to make when you’re first learning.

http://www.javaworld.com/article/2072762/java-app-dev/object-equality.html
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/13387742/compare-two-objects-with-equals-and-operator

Read full topic

item.title: What am i doing wrong
item.dc:creator: @hadlich4 hadlich4
item.description:
@hadlich4 wrote:

[quote=“tyb97, post:4, topic:546810”]I hate you Ryley, you took the easy route this time >.<

I went ahead and wrote a cleaner example.

[code=Java]
import java.util.Scanner;
import java.util.stream.Stream;

public class LoginChecker {

private static User[] users = { new User("Jim", "12345"),
		new User("Carl", "carls-password"), new User("Mopar", "or-no-car") };

public static void main(String... args) {
	Scanner scanner = new Scanner(System.in);

	System.out.println("Please enter a username.");
	String name = scanner.nextLine();
	System.out.println("Please enter the password for this account: " + name);
	String password = scanner.nextLine();
	System.out.println("Attempting to login: " + name + ", with password: " + password + ".");
	scanner.close();

	String answer = validateUser(new User(name, password)) ? "Sucessful login!" : "Login failed.";
	System.out.println(answer);
	System.exit(0);
}

private static boolean validateUser(User user) {
	return Stream.of(users).anyMatch(u -> u.equals(user));
}

private static class User {

	private String name;
	private String password;

	public User(String name, String password) {
		this.name = name;
		this.password = password;
	}

	public String getName() {
		return name;
	}

	public String getPassword() {
		return password;
	}

	@Override
	public boolean equals(Object object) {
		User user = (User) object;
		return user.getName().equalsIgnoreCase(name) && user.getPassword().equals(password);
	}
}

}[/code]

Which you can see it also did what AtomicInt_ said would fix it…

[hr]

EDIT: Turned this into a learning experience and Atomic helped me with learning some more Java 8 practices, applied in the new code, if you can be bothered to look at it OP.

[hr]

I’m so bored… Made more improvements

[code=Java]import java.util.Scanner;
import java.util.stream.Stream;

public class LoginChecker {

public static void main(String... args) {
	Scanner scanner = new Scanner(System.in);

	System.out.println("Please enter a username.");
	String name = scanner.nextLine();
	System.out.println("Please enter the password for this account: " + name);
	String password = scanner.nextLine();
	System.out.println("Attempting to login: " + name + ", with password: " + password + ".");
	scanner.close();

	String answer = validateUser(name, password) ? "Sucessful login!" : "Login failed.";
	System.out.println(answer);
	System.exit(0);
}

private static boolean validateUser(String... params) {
	return Stream.of(User.values()).anyMatch(u -> {
		if (u.getName().equalsIgnoreCase(params[0]))
			return u.getPassword().equals(params[1]);
		return false;
	});
}

private enum User {
	JIM("Jim", "12345"),
	CARL("Carl", "carls-password"),
	MOPAR("Mopar", "or-no-car");

	private String name;
	private String password;

	private User(String name, String password) {
		this.name = name;
		this.password = password;
	}

	public String getName() {
		return name;
	}

	public String getPassword() {
		return password;
	}
}

}[/code][/quote]

So where does this store username and password?

item.description:
@tyb97 wrote:

[code=Java]
import java.util.Scanner;
import java.util.stream.Stream;

public class LoginChecker {

private static User[] users = { new User("Jim", "12345"),
		new User("Carl", "carls-password"), new User("Mopar", "or-no-car") };

public static void main(String... args) {
	Scanner scanner = new Scanner(System.in);

	System.out.println("Please enter a username.");

	System.out.println("Attempting to login: " + name + ", with password: " + password + ".");
	scanner.close();

	String answer = validateUser(new User(name, password)) ? "Sucessful login!" : "Login failed.";
	System.out.println(answer);
	System.exit(0);
}

private static boolean validateUser(User user) {
	return Stream.of(users).anyMatch(u -> u.equals(user));
}

private static class User {

	private String name;
	private String password;

	public User(String name, String password) {
		this.name = name;
		this.password = password;
	}

	public String getName() {
		return name;
	}

	public String getPassword() {
		return password;
	}

	@Override
	public boolean equals(Object object) {
		User user = (User) object;
		return user.getName().equalsIgnoreCase(name) && user.getPassword().equals(password);
	}
}

}[/code]

Which you can see it also did what AtomicInt_ said would fix it…

item.title: What am i doing wrong
item.dc:creator: @hadlich4 hadlich4
item.description:
@hadlich4 wrote:

[quote=“AtomicInt_, post:2, topic:546810”][quote author=hadlich4 link=topic=665706.msg4450327#msg4450327 date=1410911868]
So I’m writing a little mini login code and this is what i got.
The problem is at void checkpassword(). The console is not noticing when the password is correct.
Sorry if my code is sloppy I’m still learning.

[code]package server;

import java.util.Scanner;
import java.io.*;

public class LauncherReworked {

//ints strings etc
static Scanner userInputScanner = new Scanner(System.in);
public static String ufloc = "";
public static String name = "";
public static String pass = "";
public static String LinNum;




  public static void main(String[] args) throws IOException {
        System.out.print("\nType Your username.");
        String Username = userInputScanner.nextLine();
        System.out.print("\nType Your password.");
        String Password = userInputScanner.nextLine();
        
        name = ""+Username+"";
        pass = ""+Password+"";
        ufloc = "C:\\Users\\PeytonAree\\workspace\\Delta Remake\\src\\characters\\"+Username+".txt";
        //find out if username is available
        
        UsernameAvailability(name);
        CheckPassword(name, pass);
        
        
        
        
  }
  
  
  
  
  
    static void ReadLines(String fileName, int startLine, int endLine)  {
		String line = null;
		int currentLineNo = 0;
		

		BufferedReader in = null;
		try {
			in = new BufferedReader (new FileReader(fileName));
	    	
			//read to startLine
			while(currentLineNo<startLine) {
				if (in.readLine()==null) {
					// oops, early end of file
					throw new IOException("File too small");
				}
				currentLineNo++;
			}
			
			//read until endLine
			while(currentLineNo<=endLine) {
				
				line = in.readLine();
				if (line==null) {
					// here, we'll forgive a short file
	// note finally still cleans up
					return;
				}
				LinNum = line;
				
				System.out.println(line);
				currentLineNo++;
			}
			
		} catch (IOException ex) {
			System.out.println("Problem reading file.\n" + ex.getMessage());
		} finally {
			try { if (in!=null) in.close(); } catch(IOException ignore) {}
		}
	}


     
     
  
  static void UsernameAvailability(String user){
	  user = ufloc;
	  File f = new File("+ufloc+");
	  
	  //if file does exist
      if (!f.isDirectory()) { 
    	  ReadLines(ufloc, 3, 3);
    	  System.out.println("not available");
    	  System.out.println(""+LinNum+"");
	  
  //if file does not exist
      } else if (!f.exists()) {
    	  System.out.println("available");
  
      }

  }
  
  
  
  static void CheckPassword(String user, String password){
		 user = ufloc;
		 password = LinNum;
		 if(pass == password){
			 System.out.println("Password Correct!");
		 } else {
			 System.out.println("Wrong Password");
		    	System.out.println("correct pass"+LinNum+"");
		 }
		 
		 
	 }

}[/code]
[/quote]

Strings cannot be compared with ==, use .equals instead.[/quote]

sweet thankyou so much learning more everyday this is awesome

Read full topic

item.title: What am i doing wrong
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

[quote=“hadlich4, post:1, topic:546810”]So I’m writing a little mini login code and this is what i got.
The problem is at void checkpassword(). The console is not noticing when the password is correct.
Sorry if my code is sloppy I’m still learning.

[code]package server;

import java.util.Scanner;
import java.io.*;

public class LauncherReworked {

//ints strings etc
static Scanner userInputScanner = new Scanner(System.in);
public static String ufloc = "";
public static String name = "";
public static String pass = "";
public static String LinNum;




  public static void main(String[] args) throws IOException {
        System.out.print("\nType Your username.");
        String Username = userInputScanner.nextLine();
        System.out.print("\nType Your password.");
        String Password = userInputScanner.nextLine();
        
        name = ""+Username+"";
        pass = ""+Password+"";
        ufloc = "C:\\Users\\PeytonAree\\workspace\\Delta Remake\\src\\characters\\"+Username+".txt";
        //find out if username is available
        
        UsernameAvailability(name);
        CheckPassword(name, pass);
        
        
        
        
  }
  
  
  
  
  
    static void ReadLines(String fileName, int startLine, int endLine)  {
		String line = null;
		int currentLineNo = 0;
		

		BufferedReader in = null;
		try {
			in = new BufferedReader (new FileReader(fileName));
	    	
			//read to startLine
			while(currentLineNo<startLine) {
				if (in.readLine()==null) {
					// oops, early end of file
					throw new IOException("File too small");
				}
				currentLineNo++;
			}
			
			//read until endLine
			while(currentLineNo<=endLine) {
				
				line = in.readLine();
				if (line==null) {
					// here, we'll forgive a short file
	// note finally still cleans up
					return;
				}
				LinNum = line;
				
				System.out.println(line);
				currentLineNo++;
			}
			
		} catch (IOException ex) {
			System.out.println("Problem reading file.\n" + ex.getMessage());
		} finally {
			try { if (in!=null) in.close(); } catch(IOException ignore) {}
		}
	}


     
     
  
  static void UsernameAvailability(String user){
	  user = ufloc;
	  File f = new File("+ufloc+");
	  
	  //if file does exist
      if (!f.isDirectory()) { 
    	  ReadLines(ufloc, 3, 3);
    	  System.out.println("not available");
    	  System.out.println(""+LinNum+"");
	  
  //if file does not exist
      } else if (!f.exists()) {
    	  System.out.println("available");
  
      }

  }
  
  
  
  static void CheckPassword(String user, String password){
		 user = ufloc;
		 password = LinNum;
		 if(pass == password){
			 System.out.println("Password Correct!");
		 } else {
			 System.out.println("Wrong Password");
		    	System.out.println("correct pass"+LinNum+"");
		 }
		 
		 
	 }

}[/code][/quote]

Strings cannot be compared with ==, use .equals instead.

Read full topic

item.title: What am i doing wrong
item.dc:creator: @hadlich4 hadlich4
item.description:
@hadlich4 wrote:

So I’m writing a little mini login code and this is what i got.
The problem is at void checkpassword(). The console is not noticing when the password is correct.
Sorry if my code is sloppy I’m still learning.

[code]package server;

import java.util.Scanner;
import java.io.*;

public class LauncherReworked {

//ints strings etc
static Scanner userInputScanner = new Scanner(System.in);
public static String ufloc = "";
public static String name = "";
public static String pass = "";
public static String LinNum;




  public static void main(String[] args) throws IOException {
        System.out.print("\nType Your username.");
        String Username = userInputScanner.nextLine();
        System.out.print("\nType Your password.");
        String Password = userInputScanner.nextLine();
        
        
        
        
        name = ""+Username+"";
        pass = ""+Password+"";
        ufloc = "C:\\Users\\PeytonAree\\workspace\\Delta Remake\\src\\characters\\"+Username+".txt";
        //find out if username is available
          PrintWriter out = new PrintWriter(new BufferedWriter(new FileWriter("C:\\Users\\PeytonAree\\workspace\\Delta Remake\\src\\characters\\"+name+".txt")));        
	         

    		
    	out.println("USERNAME =");
    	out.println(""+name+"");
        out.println("PASSWORD =");
    	out.println(""+pass+"");
    	out.close();
        

        UsernameAvailability(name);
        CheckPassword(name, pass);
        
        
        
        
  }
  
  
  
  
  
    static void ReadLines(String fileName, int startLine, int endLine)  {
		String line = null;
		int currentLineNo = 0;
		

		BufferedReader in = null;
		try {
			in = new BufferedReader (new FileReader(fileName));
	    	
			//read to startLine
			while(currentLineNo<startLine) {
				if (in.readLine()==null) {
					// oops, early end of file
					throw new IOException("File too small");
				}
				currentLineNo++;
			}
			
			//read until endLine
			while(currentLineNo<=endLine) {
				
				line = in.readLine();
				if (line==null) {
					// here, we'll forgive a short file
	// note finally still cleans up
					return;
				}
				LinNum = line;
				
				System.out.println(line);
				currentLineNo++;
			}
			
		} catch (IOException ex) {
			System.out.println("Problem reading file.\n" + ex.getMessage());
		} finally {
			try { if (in!=null) in.close(); } catch(IOException ignore) {}
		}
	}


     
     
  
  static void UsernameAvailability(String user) throws IOException{
	  user = ufloc;
	  File f = new File("+ufloc+");
	  
	  //if file does exist
      if (!f.isDirectory()) { 
    	  ReadLines(ufloc, 3, 3);
    	  System.out.println("not available");
    	  System.out.println(""+LinNum+"");



    	
	  
  //if file does not exist
      } else if (!f.exists()) {
    	  System.out.println("available");

  
      }
  }

  
  
  
  
  static void CheckPassword(String user, String password){
		 user = ufloc;
		 password = LinNum;
		 if(pass == password){
			 System.out.println("Password Correct!");
		 } else {
			 System.out.println("Wrong Password");
		    	System.out.println("correct pass"+LinNum+"");
		 }
		 
		 
	 }

}
[/code]
